The '''Autism Awareness Campaign – United Kingdom''' was launched in 2000 by British parents and carers Ivan and his wife Charika Corea in response to the [[autism]] diagnosis of their son, Charin.
==Objectives== According to their website, Autism Awareness Campaign – United Kingdom was started in 2000 "to campaign on behalf of parents, carers, children and adults with autism and [[Asperger syndrome|Asperger's syndrome]], for better public services in health, education, specialist speech therapy and respite care; for independent research into the causes of autism; for greater public awareness on Autism and Asperger's Syndrome", as well as other areas where they believe there is a shortfall in public-service provision.<ref>[http://uk_autism.tripod.com/ Autism Awareness Campaign – United Kingdom.] Official website, home page. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> They have lobbied for greater "awareness" of the condition and for independent research on the [[causes of autism]].<ref>[http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200607/cmhansrd/cm070307/halltext/70307h0009.htm#070307132000005 7 Mar 2007 : Column 497WH, Autistic Children (Education).] UK Parliament, 7 March 2007. Retrieved on 8 July 2008.</ref>
==Events== [[File:Parliament at Sunset.JPG|thumb|200px|British Prime Minister Tony Blair met with autism campaigner Ivan Corea and Lee Scott MP in the Palace of Westminster in 2007 to discuss autism]] [[File:15-11-05 101 Monument.jpg|thumb|200px|London 2012 Olympic bid]] ;2002 United Kingdom Autism Awareness Year
The Autism Awareness Campaign of 2002 initiated debates in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament of the UK]] and the [[Scottish Parliament]] for Autism Awareness Year, supported by 800 UK organisations including the British Institute of Brain Injured Children, The Disabilities Trust, Autism London and the [[National Autistic Society]].<ref name=UKParliament9Jan>[http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200102/cmhansrd/vo020109/halltext/20109h02.htm 9 Jan 2002 : Column 226WH, Autism.] UK Parliament, 9 January 2002. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> A major conference on autism was held at the [[King's Fund]] in London and the first ever service for autism was launched in 2002 by the couple who initiated [[Autism Sunday]] - it was held at [[St Paul's Cathedral]]. Autism Sunday is now a massive worldwide event, celebrated in many countries.
;2007 House of Commons autism debate and meeting with Prime Minister The Autism Awareness Campaign helped raise "awareness" about the condition in 2007 in the [[British House of Commons]] when [[Lee Scott (UK politician)|Lee Scott]], MP for [[Ilford North (UK Parliament constituency)|Ilford North]], brought a debate on autistic children.<ref>[http://www.bloggernews.net/15126 UK Autism Westminster Debate: British MPs focus attention onto Autism.] Blogger News Network, 10 March 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref>
Ivan Corea met with the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]], [[Tony Blair]] and Lee Scott MP in April 2007. He presented the Prime Minister with a report calling for a national strategy on autism and a 10-year plan of action in the UK.<ref>[http://www.number-10.gov.uk/output/Page11529.asp PM praised for speaking out on autism.] 10 Downing Street, 25 April 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> The call for an urgent review on autism services was supported by leading British charities and community organisations including faith communities.<ref>[http://www.huliq.com/20018/uk-prime-minister-tony-blair-meets-autism-campaigners UK Prime Minister Tony Blair meets Autism Campaigners.] Huliq News 27 April 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> Parliamentarians signed an [[early day motion]] on autism (EDM 1359) backing the call for a national strategy on autism and change in policy for people with autism and [[Asperger syndrome]].<ref>Gapes, Mike. [http://edmi.parliament.uk/edmi/EDMDetails.aspx?EDMID=33138&SESSION=885 Early Day Motion: EDM 1359 on Autism.] House of Commons - UK Parliament, 26 April 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> Ivan Corea met with the British Prime Minister-in-Waiting, [[Gordon Brown]] in June 2007 to urge him to launch the national strategy and 10-year plan on autism,<ref name=BrownUrged>[http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/74559.php Gordon Brown Urged To Take Decisive Action On Autism.] Medical News Today, 19 June 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> particularly in building state-of-the-art "autism schools".<ref>[http://www.channel4.com/news/articles/society/health/help+autistic+children++call/591682 Help Autistic Children.] Channel 4 Television, 8 July 2007. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref>
'''World Autism Awareness Day'''
The Autism Awareness Campaign UK were involved in the first United Nations World Autism Awareness Day, declared by the [[UN General Assembly]] on Wednesday 2 April 2008 on the recommendation of the State of [[Qatar]].
The campaign called on the United Nations Secretary-General, [[Ban Ki-moon]] to launch a world autism strategy. A CNN interview with presenter Max Foster was televised to mark World Autism Awareness Day on 2 April 2008.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/video/#/video/health/2008/04/02/intv.austism.corea.cnn Fighting for Autism: Max Foster interviews Ivan Corea.] CNN.com, 2 April 2008. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref> International coverage about the Autism Awareness Campaign UK was also given on [[Associated Press]] and the campaigners received national coverage in the United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.gm.tv/index.cfm?articleid=28952 GMTV features the Autism Awareness Campaign UK]. GMTV, 25 April 2008. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref>
The campaigners released a film to mark the United Nations World Autism Awareness Day with British peer the [[Baroness Uddin]] in the [[House of Lords]].[[Open Every Door]], written by the award winning Sri Lanka-born singer and songwriter, [[Nimal Mendis]], was aired on the UN World Autism Awareness Day by CNN.
'''London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic bid''' [[Sebastian Coe|Lord Coe]] appointed Ivan Corea as a [[London 2012 Olympic bid]] Ambassador; the Autism Awareness Campaign UK were fully involved with the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic bid.<ref>[http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/search/575826.Buckhurst_Hill_man_called_up_to_back_Olympic_bid/ Buckhurst Hill man called up to back Olympic bid.] ''The Guardian'', 8 March 2005. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/search/575199.Support_for_Olympics_results_in_special_posting/ Support for Olympics results in special posting.] ''The Guardian'', 7 March 2005. Retrieved on 20 July 2008.</ref>
